Class ArgumentType<T>

java.lang.Object
lanat.utils.errors.ErrorContainerImpl<ArgumentTypeError>
lanat.ArgumentType<T>
Type Parameters:
T - The type of the value that this argument type will parse into.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Parseable<T>, ErrorContainer<ArgumentTypeError>, NamedWithDescription, ParentElementGetter<ArgumentType<?>>, PostCreationInheritor<Command>, Resettable
Direct Known Subclasses:
ActionArgumentType, BooleanArgumentType, CounterArgumentType, DummyArgumentType, FileArgumentType, FromParseableArgumentType, KeyValuesArgumentType, NumberArgumentType, NumberRangeArgumentType, SimpleArgumentType, SingleValueListArgumentType, StdinArgumentType, StringArgumentType, TryParseArgumentType, TupleArgumentType
public abstract class ArgumentType<T> extends ErrorContainerImpl<ArgumentTypeError> implements Resettable, Parseable<T>, ParentElementGetter<ArgumentType<?>>, PostCreationInheritor<Command>

Argument Type

An Argument Type is a handler in charge of parsing a specific kind of input from the command line. For example, the IntegerArgumentType is in charge of parsing integers from the command line.

Creating custom Argument Types

Creating new Argument Types is an easy task. Extending this class already provides you with most of the functionality that you need. The minimum method that should be implemented is the Parseable.parseValues(String[]) method. Which will be called by the main parser when it needs to parse the values of an argument of this type.

The custom Argument Type can push errors to the main parser by using the addError(String) method and its overloads.

It is possible to use other Argument Types inside your custom Argument Type. This is done by using the registerSubType(ArgumentType) method. This allows you to listen for errors that occur in the subtypes, and to add them to the list of errors of the main parser. onSubTypeError(ArgumentTypeError) is called when an error occurs in a subtype.

You can also implement Parseable to create a basic argument type implementation. Note that in order to use that implementation, you need to wrap it in a FromParseableArgumentType instance (which provides the necessary internal functionality).

      protected final void registerSubType(@NotNull @NotNull ArgumentType<?> subType)

    • onSubTypeError

      protected void onSubTypeError(@NotNull @NotNull ArgumentTypeError error)
      This is called when a subtype of this argument type has an error. By default, this adds the error to the list of errors, while also adding the currentArgValueIndex to the error's token index.
      Parameters:
      error - The error that occurred in the subtype.
